intro: Acacia distans, commonly known as the slender acacia, is a shrub native to the arid and semi-arid regions of Africa. It is characterized by its slender, often multi-branched stems and small, feathery leaves that reduce water loss. The plant produces yellow flowers in compact globular clusters, which are followed by long, flat pods containing seeds. Acacia distans is well adapted to drought conditions, making it a hardy species in sandy or rocky soils. It is also known for its ability to fix nitrogen, contributing to soil fertility in its native habitat.

Its genus is Acacia, a large group of shrubs and trees known for their distinctive foliage and often used for timber, fodder, or ornamental purposes. Its species is Acacia distans, a specific type of acacia found in certain regions, known for its unique morphology and ecological adaptations.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acacia distans is primarily native to Western Australia. It is found in the southern and western regions of the state, particularly in the area known as the Geraldton area. This species typically grows in sandy soils and is adapted to the arid and semi-arid climates of the region. It is commonly found in coastal and inland areas, often forming part of the vegetation in shrublands and woodlands. Acacia distans plays an important ecological role in its native habitat, providing food and shelter for various wildlife species.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acacia distans was mainly introduced to control soil erosion and as a windbreak in arid and semi-arid regions. It is commonly used in reclamation projects due to its ability to thrive in poor soil conditions. The plant is also valued for its hardy nature and capacity to fix nitrogen, improving soil fertility. However, its introduction has led to some ecological concerns in certain areas. It is now widely distributed across parts of Africa, the Middle East, and Australia.
